title: NY businesses ordered to further reduce employees in workplaces
summary:
"I understand that this is a burden to businesses," Cuomo said of an order that is going to further hit an already battered state economy.
Cuomo repeated a voluntary request: that all businesses have employees work from home if they can.
Firms that size with revenues last year of $1 million or more must give five paid sick days and then be eligible for paid family leave benefits until quarantines end.
Those with 11 to 99 workers have to also offer five paid sick days, while employers with 100 or more workers must provide at least 14 paid sick days to ill or quarantined employees.
All state and local government agencies must provide such covered employees with at least 14 paid sick days.

title: Thomas R. Hess, 94, WWII veteran and painting contractor was familiar face in ads
summary:

His friends teased him when he first started modeling, but, Mr. Hess said, "I laughed all the way to the bank."
Mr. Hess was born on Jan. 4, 1926, the oldest of four sons of William J. and Frances Wood Hess.
After the war ended, Mr. Hess attended Canisius College, where he was elected president of the Glee Club in 1949.

title: WGR-AM to air Bills' 'The Comeback Game' as part of classic games series

title: Buffalo breaks high temperature record for January 11th
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Early this afternoon the temperature went above 61 degrees which was the record high temperature for this date.
Later in the afternoon the National Weather Service Buffalo announced Buffalo reached a high temperature of 67 degrees which tied for the seventh warmest January day on record and the warmest January day since 2005.
The temperature at #Buffalo this early afternoon has reached 67°F.
This is tied for 7th warmest January day on record...and is the warmest January temperature since January 13, 2005 when it was 68°F.
All-time warmest temperature at Buffalo is 72°F set back on January 25th, 1950.

title: Heavy snow due as sprawling storm spreads across New York
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (AP) — A sprawling winter storm that canceled flights and coated roads over much of the country was expected to dump up to a foot of snow on parts of New York state starting Saturday.
Snow and freezing was falling in the Buffalo area on Saturday morning as the storm began tracking across the state.
Parts of northern New York east of Lake Ontario were forecast to get up to a foot of snow by Monday morning, as were some towns near Lake Erie, south of Buffalo, according to the National Weather Service.
Snow and then rain were expected to push into New York City on Saturday afternoon.
Forecasters say the metropolitan area could end up with several inches of snow.

title: Powerful winds cause damage across Western New York
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Intense winds from Saturday night's storm battered Hoover Beach with more debris, caused power outages, and uprooted trees across Western New York.
The wind pushed water on to the home fronts of Hoover Beach as the area saw its third major storm in just over three months.
"We just can't take anymore of this it's to much," said Hoover Beach homeowner Sam Insalaco.
Town of Hamburg Emergency Manager Sean Crotty said Hamburg is submitting hundreds of thousands in expenses from the storms to FEMA.
Western New York experienced uprooted trees, including this one in Lancaster.

title: Significant power outages reported Sunday morning
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — UPDATE : NYSEG has released an estimated time of restoration for customers impacted by Sunday’s weather saying that it expects to restore all customers impacted in the affected areas by 11:30 p.m. Monday.
While the company has completed restoration to more than 63,000 customers, roughly 3,000 customers primarily located in Lancaster and Cheektowaga will not be restored until tomorrow due to the extent of the damage in those areas.
By 1 p.m, National Grid reported around 5,000 customers remained without power in the region.
At that time, NYSEG reported 12,000 without power in Erie County, down from around 40,000 there in the early morning hours.
The most affected locales were Lancaster, Depew, Clarence, Alden and Elma.

title: Gas prices finally begin to drop across Western New York
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — If you're looking for some relief at the gas pump, you're in luck.
Gas prices are starting to fall across Western New York following a significant period of high prices due to ongoing tensions in the Middle East.
According to AAA of Western and Central New York, the average price for a gallon of gas in Buffalo is $2.63, a one-cent decrease from last week, while the average price for gas in Batavia is $2.64 per gallon, a three-cent decrease from last week.
Gas prices in Western New York are higher than the national average of $2.55 per gallon, however they're lower than the statewide average of $2.71 per gallon.

title: The local job market takes a turn for the worse in January
summary:
The Buffalo Niagara job market took a turn for the worse in January, just weeks before concerns over the coronavirus outbreak started sending shock waves through the economy.
The January slump, combined with major revisions to last year’s numbers that showed the local job market fell into decline last July, paint a picture of a sluggish employment market during a time when the national economy was still going strong.
And despite the job losses, unemployment remains low by local standards.
Glass thinks job losses are partly because it’s hard for businesses to find workers.
Construction and the education and health services sector were the hot spots in an otherwise weak local job market during January.

title: Minimum wage to increase in Western New York on New Year's Eve
summary:
ALBANY, N.Y. (WKBW) — As New York begins to raise the minimum wage to $15 per hour statewide, Gov.
Andrew Cuomo (D-NY) says minimum wage workers in Western New York will see an increase by the new year.
Starting Dec. 31, the minimum wage in Western New York will increase to $11.80 per hour, from $11.10 per hour.
"New York is leading the fight for economic justice, proudly setting a national example by raising the minimum wage to $15," Gov.
As for when Western New York will see a minimum wage increase to $15, Cuomo did not set a specific date, while saying it will be up to the Director of the Division of Budget and the New York State Department of Labor.

title: Don't expect this weekend's weather to fill in our snowfall deficit
summary:
This weekend’s storm system will come up short for filling in our snowfall deficit.
November was actually colder than average by nearly 5 degrees and snowfall was nearly 4 inches above average.
Since then, real winter weather has been in short supply.
December was 11.3 inches below average for snow and 3.2 degrees milder than average.
As we head into late January, only 11.7 inches has fallen, and we are more than 15 inches below average for the season.

title: Wind gust of 69mph at airport, thousands without power
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Thousands NYSEG customers and hundres of National Grid customers are without power Sunday as hurricane-force winds whipped through Western New York.
The National Weather Service recorded a peak gust of 69mph at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport in Cheektowaga.
The airport was without power Sunday morning causing flight delays, a spokesperson from the NFTA released this statement:"We are back to full power at the Buffalo Airport.
Power was down since early this morning due to the outages caused by the wind storm and was back up just after 10 this morning."
The wind storm follows a day of record breaking warmth, with a high of 67 degrees at the airport.

title: If the Calendar Says January, Why Does the Thermometer Say May?
summary:
It sure didn’t feel like January in the Northeast over the past few days.
Records for daily highs were broken from Columbus, Ohio, and Pittsburgh to New York City and Bangor, Maine.
Many residents took the warm spell as a belated holiday gift and went outside to cycle or jog or picnic with friends and family as if it were spring.
Buffalo, where the temperature on the same date last year never went above 20, reached 67 on Saturday.
But what was that anomalous warm spell all about?

title: Buffalo in third place for New York’s snowiest city
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB)–While Buffalo is just seeing the return of old man winter, we have a long way to go if we want to retain our title for the Golden Snowball.
The award is given to New York’s snowiest city.
Right now, Rochester is in the lead.
They’ve received nearly 59 inches of snow this year.
Buffalo is in third with about 40 inches for the season so far.

title: Third confirmed flu-related pediatric death in New York State
summary:
NEW YORK (WKBW) — 11-year-old Luca Calanni of Hamburg, who was laid to rest Saturday morning, was one of two flu-related pediatric deaths in New York this flu season and the New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) has confirmed there has now been a third.
The information was disclosed in the NYSDOH Weekly Influenza Surveillance Report, a spokesperson with the NYSDOH confirmed to 7 Eyewitness News the death occurred in Central New York.
Erie County health officials said in early January normally influenza strain A occurs around this time and influenza strain B occurs around March or April, but officials were seeing strain B much earlier in the season.
New York State's online flu tracker shows the state has had nearly 44,000 cases of the flu reported as of the week ending January 11th.
Local daycare facilities are also doing what they can to help prevent the spread of the flu.

This bedazzling event has become one of the Buffalo and Erie County Botanical Gardens’ most celebrated affairs, due to its brilliant light and sound elements.
Aquarium members, with a valid ID, receive Botanical Garden Member pricing on January 26.
Albright-Knox members, with valid ID, receive Botanical Garden Member pricing this night.
Audubon members with valid ID receive Botanical Garden Member pricing this night.
Botanical Gardens’ guest passes, discounts and coupons are not valid during Lumagination.

title: Hundreds rally at Buffalo Women's March
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Hundreds stood in front of Buffalo City Hall, on Sunday.
Women's Marches like these were happening all across the country this weekend.
Women were fighting for all sorts of causes: reproductive rights, transgender rights, fighting racism or protesting military action in the Middle East.
But even in their division, there was unity.
“We're bridging gaps between ages, races, faiths and hopefully between people and the law makers,” said Denise Robinson.

title: How much snow fell in Upstate NY weekend storm (Jan. 17-19)?
summary:
Syracuse, N.Y. -- The first substantial snowstorm of 2020 dropped as much as 2 feet in Upstate New York over the weekend.
The biggest totals were on hills and in the lake effect areas downwind of lakes Erie and Ontario.
The Wyoming County village of Wyoming, elevation 988 feet and east of Lake Erie, had 27.5 inches.
In second place, with 23 inches, was the Lewis County town of Osceola, which sits at nearly 1,700 feet at the eastern end of Lake Ontario.
The snow is likely to stick around through the middle of the week, but start to melt Thursday and Friday as temperatures rise into the 40s across much of Upstate.

title: WNY hospitals hit hard with flu
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Flu season continues to hit hard across the United states.
Western New York hospitals are seeing an increase in flu cases.
The continued increase in flu cases is impacting ERs in the area.
The emergency department has seen more than 1,000 positive flu cases and flu season may not have even hit peak yet.
"We had about 8 kids admitted with the flu last season at this time and we've admitted over 50 so far this year.

title: Early arrival of flu strikes thousands across New York State
summary:
A lot more people than usual spent the holidays at home or in the hospital with the flu, thanks to an early arrival of the contagious respiratory illness in New York State.
In Erie County, reported flu cases more than doubled each week of December, climbing from 29 cases the first week to 345 cases the last week of the year.
The state Health Department reported 10,085 laboratory-confirmed cases of the flu statewide during the week ending Jan. 4.
The numbers are underreported because not everyone who gets the flu seeks treatment, and not all cases that test positive are reported to the state.
Seniors, pregnant women and children under age 2 are considered at high risk for the flu, according to health experts.

title: Meeting set amid alarm over longer New York State Fair
summary:
The New York State Fair will host a meeting next Friday near Syracuse for administrators from nine county fairs throughout the state – including Erie County – that would be affected by a plan to lengthen the state fair by five days.
Jessica Underberg, chief executive officer of the Erie County Fair and Erie County Agricultural Society, said state fair director Troy Waffner set up the gathering after he called Underberg Thursday to discuss the proposed change.
The state fair and the Erie County Fair both reported more than 1 million visitors a year ago, and the two landmark upstate events traditionally maintain a few days of August separation between closing day in Erie County and opening day at the state fair.
Waffner has pledged to address any conflicts or inconveniences that an 18-day state fair might cause for vendors and exhibitors.
"I'm hoping we can get some answers about how the state fair will schedule those events," he said.

title: 6 soups to try at Buffalo Soup-Fest 2020
summary:
While hearty chicken noodle soup, a bowl of long-simmering pho or a cup of French onion lurking beneath bubbly cheese might be your personal favorite, Buffalo Soup-Fest is the annual opportunity to try something less traditional.
Check out the full slate of restaurants and the menu of soups offered at Soup-Fest, then continue with several suggestions below.
(The soup, both vegan and gluten-free, captured Best Soup at the inaugural Buffalo Soup-Fest, Davidson said, if you needed any more convincing to try it).
The Howling Rooster's chicken wing soupThere's not a standard chicken wing soup in Buffalo, even if Danny's – another Soup-Fest winner – is the best known.
The Howling Rooster's house soup is chicken wing, as the restaurant-bar on the edge of Kenmore and Buffalo rolls through a 5-gallon batch each week.

title: Six people affected, firefighter taken to hospital after South Buffalo fire
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — Six people are being helped by the Red Cross and a firefighter was taken to the hospital after a fire in South Buffalo.
The fire at the multi-unit building on Southside Parkway began after 10 p.m. Saturday.
Fire investigators believe the fire began at the basement.
Damage was estimated at $275,000.
There was no initial indication from city officials on the severity of the firefighter’s injuries.

title: 5 compelling food and drink events for January in Buffalo
summary:
January sparkles with these annual events, enticing attendees with gooey macaroni and cheese, hard-to-find craft beers and stomach-warming soups.
Here are five worth considering, with all but one of the events presenting multiple sessions.
Buffalo on Tap, two sessions: 1 to 4 p.m. and 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. Jan. 11 in the Buffalo Niagara Convention Center (153 Franklin St.); americaontap.com.
America on Tap craft beer events now extend from Honolulu to Maine, and this is the eighth annual event in the Buffalo Niagara Convention Center.
Buffalo Soup-Fest, two sessions: 11 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 3 to 5:30 p.m. Jan. 26 at Buffalo RiverWorks (359 Ganson St.); buffalosoupfest.com.

title: Red Cross in critical need of donations from people with 'O' blood type
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — The American Red Cross is asking for your help in donating blood, due to a critical shortage of type 'O' blood.
The Red Cross says this shortage is the result of winter weather threatening to cancel blood drives, and the rise of the flu preventing people from giving blood.
As of Monday, the Red Cross has a less than three-day supply of type O blood for patient emergencies and medical treatments.

title: Weekend forecast: Snow, gusty winds
summary:
Some parts of southern Erie County and the Southern Tier may see a foot to 18 inches of snow this weekend, according to the National Weather Service.
Snow and blowing snow, with continued windy conditions, are forecast for Sunday.
A long duration snow event will occur across our region starting Saturday morning as widespread snow and ending Sunday and Sunday night as lake effect snow.
Through midday Friday, 34.3 inches of snow have fallen at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport for the season, according to the weather service.
Normally, 50.1 inches of snow usually falls during the season through Jan. 16, according to weather service data.

title: Lake Erie is ice-free. Will that mean another snowy January?
summary:
At this point in the season, about a quarter of Lake Erie is usually covered with ice.
This year, once again, Lake Erie is still free of ice.
So does that mean we’re likely to get socked with mounds of lake-effect snow?
But just because there is an unusually open lake right now does not mean we’re in for an unusually snowy month.
That year, about 16% of Lake Erie was frozen in early January.

title: Public input wanted on Buffalo Skyway project
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — In September 2019, Governor Andrew Cuomo announced the winning proposal in the Skyway Corridor Competition.
Courtesy NYS Empire State DevelopmentThe public will have a chance to learn more about the proposal and offer feedback during two Scoping Meetings today (January 28) being held by the NYS Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) and the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA).
People attending the meetings will also have a chance to review options for traffic flow assuming the Skyway is no longer in use from Church Street to Tift Street.
Courtesy NYS Empire State DevelopmentA piece of the Skyway high-level bridge will be re-purposed as "Skyway Park" to provide iconic views and recreational options.
The Buffalo Skyway was completed in the 1950's and carries and estimated 40,000 trips per day of commuter traffic.

title: The Fishing Beat for Jan. 1, 2020
summary:
The Fishing Beat for Jan. 1, 2020It’s a new year and a new decade.
Jan. 1 kicks off new seasons like lake trout season in the lower Niagara River and Lake Ontario.
For phase 1, all boat operators born on or after Jan. 1, 1993 must complete a safety course to operate a motorized vessel starting in 2020.
Niagara RiverNiagara River water was starting to change for the worse on Tuesday after the heavy rains followed by winds.
Lake trout season is open as of Jan. 1 in the lower river.

title: Pearl Jam announces first new album in seven years, 2020 North American tour
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Pearl Jam is making headlines in the music world.
For the first time in seven years, the band is putting out a new album.
Announcing Gigaton: A new album and tour coming Spring 2020!
More info at https://t.co/uDIWRrKT1y pic.twitter.com/AwECDMa5Zz — Pearl Jam (@PearlJam) January 13, 2020According to the band, the new album, titled "Gigaton," will be out on March 27.
But it will come out just a couple of weeks after they begin a 2020 North American Tour.

title: Double shooting leaves two Buffalo teens in critical condition
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Buffalo police say two teens, a 17 year old and an 18 year old, are in critical condition at ECMC after a double shooting on Wednesday evening.
Police say the shooting happened around 5:30 p.m. in the 300 block of Woodlawn Avenue in the Ferry-Fillmore district.
Investigators say the incident appears targeted in nature.
Anyone with information is asked to call police.

title: 3.3 magnitude earthquake shakes northern New York
summary:
ORMSTOWN, Canada (WIVB) — People in northern New York surely felt the shaking of an earthquake early Monday morning.
On a map, the epicenter of the 3.3 magnitude quake was just above the New York-Canada border, northwest of Plattsburgh.
More than 10 kilometers deep, the earthquake was reported around 5:38 a.m. EST.

title: Wegmans to eliminate plastic bags from all New York stores on January 27th
summary:
Wegmans says starting on January 27th, you'll no longer see single-use plastic grocery bags in stores.
The announcement comes just months before the state's ban on such bags goes into effect.
According to Wegmans, the grocery store will charge a fee of five cents per paper bag used, and the money collected from the paper bag fee will go towards FeedMore WNY.
The statewide ban goes into effect on March 1.
Tops Friendly Markets told 7 Eyewitness News it plans to eliminate the single-use bags at that time.

summary:
The past is a theme that connects several worthy events for this week in Buffalo.

Cami Clune and Tommy's Acoustic Experience, 8:10 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 16 at 189 Burger (189 Main St., East Aurora).

title: Storm Team 2’s 2019-2020 winter forecast
summary:
In fact, if two snow days in late January were removed, Buffalo’s 2018-2019 snow total would have been 30 inches lower.
Winter ClimatologyBuffalo’s “normal” snowfall total of 94 inches is the average season total between the years of 1981 and 2010.
But data through the past 50 years indicates that that average snowfall amount may be increasing.
Related: Watch Climate MinuteData also shows that Western New York’s snow season may be shrinking and shifting.
There is also a slight but notable decrease in average snowfall for November, but an increase in snowfall for March.

title: 2 arrested following arson in Buffalo involving Molotov cocktails
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — Buffalo fire officials are investigating an arson on Breckenridge St.
Firefighters went to the scene at 171 Breckenridge Wednesday around 5:30 a.m.
According to prosecutors, two women threw a number of bottles with gasoline and ignited wicks into the lower level of the multi-family home.
A Buffalo police officer was taken to ECMC for smoke inhalation.
On Thursday, we learned Ayesha Patterson, 28, and Latoya Austin, 41, have been charged with first-degree arson and multiple counts of criminal mischief and reckless endangerment.

title: Bakery owner suing over building collapse
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB)–The owner of a bakery in Buffalo is suing her landlord.
Two Wheels Bakery was based in a building on Ellicott Street which has been torn down.
In the suit, Two Wheels said the building was declared “uninhabitable” after a partial collapse back in August, forcing the bakery to close.
The roof gave way last month.
Two Wheels is claiming negligence and fraud, and is seeking damages for its business property that they were not allow to remove from the site.

title: Demolition of Buffalo's Shoreline Apartments to begin at the end of January
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — We have an update to a story we have been following closely in the past few weeks on 7 Eyewitness News.
We have learned crews plan to start demolition of the old Shoreline Apartments on Niagara Street in Buffalo at the end of the month.
The developer is still working through final approvals and is in the process of notifying residents.
Over the summer, the owners at Norstar Development said there was a hold-up because of an on-going court case, but we're told now that case is over.

title: Buffalo, WNY taking baby steps into the 'smart city' movement
summary:
Buffalo is still far from becoming the “smart city” Mayor Byron Brown promised in a February address.
But both the city and the wider Western New York region are taking baby steps into the smart-city movement.
The Buffalo Niagara Medical Campus is pitching a long-awaited Main Street “smart corridor.” And in February, the city of Buffalo is expected to make a series of announcements on upcoming technological and infrastructure investments.
It’s all part of a long-term push to harness connected sensors, cameras and other tools to optimize public services.
But Brown said “smart” technologies, such as the ones his administration proposes, have the potential to improve services for everyone.

title: LaMONTE, Nicholas Francis
summary:
LaMONTE, Nicholas Francis "Nick"LaMONTE - Nicholas Francis "Nick"83, died Sunday, December 8, 2019 in Las Vegas, NV.
Throughout his life, Nick had various occupations that consisted of working for the NY State United Teachers both in Buffalo, NY and Grand Island, NY.
He made many charitable contributions not only to the Red Cross, but also to the Catholic Church, the US Veterans organization in Las Vegas, NV, Big Brothers and Big Sisters of Southern Nevada, and the homeless community in Las Vegas, NV.
He was preceded in death by his parents Louis and Mary LaMonte; his wife Jeannette LaMonte; and his eldest brother Louie LaMonte.
A Memorial Mass will be held 11:00 am on Tuesday, January 14, 2020 at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton church, 1811 Pueblo Vista Drive, Las Vegas, NV with Fr.

title: Uptick in coronavirus cases leads to a state of emergency for New York
summary:
Andrew Cuomo declared a state of emergency Saturday as he confirmed 89 cases of the coronavirus known as COVID-19 in New York – including the first cases upstate.
The new cases the governor announced Saturday are, again, primarily downstate, so Western New York remains spared of any confirmed cases of the coronavirus so far.
The Erie County Health Department is monitoring 116 people in quarantine for potential exposure to novel coronavirus.
Of the 89 confirmed coronavirus cases in New York, 10 of the patients remain hospitalized.
Cuomo has also suspended visiting at nursing homes, assisted living facilities and senior housing in the New Rochelle area because of the number of COVID-19 cases in that region.

title: Water main break slows traffic in Buffalo
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Buffalo police have issued a traffic alert due to a water main break.
Authorities say lane restrictions will remain in place for a few days following a water main break on Main Street and Jefferson Avenue.
Traffic Alert: Due to overnight water main break at Main Street & Jefferson Avenue, lane restrictions will be in place for a few days.
@NFTAMetro Rail will not run to/from Delavan Station this morning due to an overnight water main break.
Stay up to date with 7 First Alert Traffic, here.

title: 2 men killed on Gorton Street in Buffalo
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) —UPDATE– Buffalo police say two men are dead in connection with Friday night’s shooting inside of a home on Gorton Street.
Detectives say a 30-year-old man died at the scene and a 29-year-old man died while being transported to ECMC.
Buffalo police say the incident appears targeted in nature.
ORIGINAL –One man is dead and another was hospitalized following a shooting on Gorton St. in Buffalo.
They say the men were shot inside the building.

title: SWAT situation in North Buffalo ends peacefully
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — A SWAT situation in North Buffalo has ended peacefully.
Buffalo police say they were called to the 300 block of Sanders Road, near Colvin Avenue, for a welfare check involving two young children around 7:30 p.m. Tuesday.
Our 7 Eyewitness News crew at the scene saw one person being taken into custody.
Buffalo SWAT and the Crisis Management Team responded to the call.
We will have more information on this as it becomes available.

title: Catholic Health welcomes first baby of 2020
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — Catholic Health has welcomed its first baby of 2020.
Eden Rose Sadler was born at Sisters of Charity Hospital at 1:35 a.m. She weighs six pounds and 13.2 oz, and is 18.78 inches long.
She and her mother, Julia, are doing well.
This year, all first-born babies at Catholic Health’s maternity hospitals (Sisters of Charity Hospital Main Campus, Mount St. Mary’s Hospital and Mercy Hospital of South Buffalo) were girls.
We will share a photo of baby Eden when it’s available!

title: High temps, little snow: Winter 2020 is Buffalo's ninth-warmest on record
summary:
This winter was the ninth-warmest on record in Buffalo, according to the National Weather Service.
Temperatures in December, January and February, which typically average about 27 degrees, rarely fell below 20 degrees, even at night, weather service data shows.
“The biggest thing with lake-effect – and there’s a lot to it – is being cold,” Apffel said.
Because "climate" refers to weather conditions over a long period, a single warm or cold winter doesn’t, on its own, communicate much about it.
As for what’s coming next, the weather service forecasts that March, April and May will also skew warmer than usual.

title: One more warm day before Western New York dives back into a wintry pattern
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — You have one more day of warmth before Old Man Winter returns from vacation and sticks around for a while.
But before we get to the cold, your Tuesday and Wednesday is looking comfortable for a winter day.
The first good shot of cold will push into Western New York Thursday, bringing with it wind, snow, and tricky travel spots.
Your Friday is looking cold and with some lake flakes south of Buffalo to start the day.
And when you think things will warm up Saturday, think again.

title: High Wind Watch in place for much of Western New York starting late Saturday Night
summary:
The National Weather Service has issued a High Wind Watch for Niagara, Erie, Orleans, Genesee, Chautauqua, Cattaraugus and Wyoming County starting late Saturday night.
Some areas could see would gusts as high as 60 mph Sunday morning.
Wind gusts will be strong enough to create isolated power outages and uproot trees.
Much of Western New York is also under a Flood Watch.
The flood watch goes into place Saturday afternoon.

title: Western New York prepares to help Puerto Rico after earthquakes
summary:
Chito Olivencia, a leader in the Western New York Puerto Rican community, told 2 On Your Side, "People are scared.
The local community is meeting Thursday night to discuss ways to assist the people of Puerto Rico.
(Kevin P. Coughlin/Office of Governor Andrew M. Cuomo)Kevin P. Coughlin/Office of Governor Andrew M. CuomoGovernor Cuomo has already authorized the deployment of 115 National Guard members to Puerto Rico.
A press conference is being held Saturday at The Belle Center at 1 p.m. to announce more fundraising efforts for Puerto Rico.

title: Winning Buffalo Skyway plan might not be the final plan
summary:
People can view, discuss and submit comments about the various Skyway plans tonight (January 29) until 8 p.m. at the Southside Elementary School in South Buffalo (430 Southside Parkway).
For those who cannot make the session, comments can still be submitted to buffalo.skyway@dot.ny.gov, or by U.S. mail to Buffalo Skyway Project Team, NYSDOT Region 5, 100 Seneca Street, Buffalo, NY 14203.
Many people are confused because in September 2019, officials awarded a $100,000 prize to a Rochester firm after submitting the winning plans in the "Aim for the Sky" competition for the Buffalo Skyway Corridor.
"There was a design concept that won, however, that is not the only concept being considered for the Buffalo Skyway," said Susan Surdej, regional public information officer for NYSDOT.
You can view the top submissions for the "Aim for the Sky" competition by clicking here.

summary:
MECHANICSBURG, Pa. — One of Western New York's most prominent developers has been killed in a helicopter crash in Central Pennsylvania.
We have a long way to go to understand what occurred," Senior Air Safety Investigator with the NTSB, Tim Monville, said.

title: Buffalo Bert predicts 6 more weeks of Winter
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB)–It’s six extra weeks of winter if you ask Buffalo’s dynamic groundhog duo, the real animal Buffalo Bert, and his costume-clad mother, Buffalo Mack.
Western New Yorkers celebrated the 7th Annual Buffalo Groundhog Day at Flying Bison Brewing Company.
The unofficial holiday was started by a group of Buffalo enthusiasts who felt this region’s infamous weather was deserving of its own Groundhog Day.
The local nonprofit has raised over $21,000 dollars for local animals in need since its inception.
The traditional Groundhog Day is next Sunday.

title: Birders brave bitter Buffalo cold in search of the snowy owl
summary:
Debbie Ehms and Susan Patterson came from Tonawanda to search the Buffalo waterfront on one of the coldest days of the year.
You can see them and others with binoculars, scopes and sometimes telephoto lenses, gazing out over the water just like the objective of their quest: the snowy owl.
Birders and bird lovers have been captivated in recent weeks by sightings of snowy owls in Buffalo.
"Everyone was saying they’ve been seeing a snowy owl here and at the Erie Basin Marina.
But snowy owls are not usually susceptible to disturbance by large crowds or individuals, he said.

title: Western New York hospitals obtain highly regarded designations naming them breast feeding leaders
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — Until December of 2019 Western New York had no “baby-friendly” hospitals.
According to the list, The Ten Steps to Successful Breastfeeding are:Have a written breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all health care staff.
Foster the establishment of breastfeeding support groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or birth center.
Oishei Children’s Hospital was the first to receive the highly-regarded designation, and Mother-Baby Unit Nurse leader Cheryl Madge says it was not an easy process.
Skin-to-skin contact and general bonding with mothers are central aspects of the practices post-labor at Oishei Children’s Hospital.

title: Nursing home COVID-19 reporting not transparent enough for Erie County Legislature
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — The Erie County Health and Human Services committee is pushing for more transparency when it comes to nursing home deaths.
Legislator Lisa Chimera, who chairs the committee said she wants two things: family members to be notified faster, and numbers released to the public.
As of April 13, there have been 36 deaths in Erie County nursing homes and adult care facilities.
Chimera wants the State health department, who oversees enforcing the reporting of deaths, to wark more closely with local departments of health to distribute data faster.
The Department will continue to work with administrators of private and county nursing homes to do everything possible to protect the health, well-being and privacy of the residents who call these facilities home.”Here is the specific guidance NYSDOH released to nursing homes in regards to notifying families.

title: Plunge in New York manufacturing is far worse than during Great Recession
summary:
The downturn in manufacturing across New York is far worse than anything that happened during the Great Recession more than a decade ago, a new report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found.
The Fed's monthly Empire State Manufacturing Survey, released Wednesday, found that business activity plunged dramatically in early April, with 85% of the manufacturers surveyed reporting that conditions had worsened.
It was a broad-based decline, with new orders, shipments, employment and the length of the average workweek all falling sharply.
"Firms anticipate only a small improvement in business conditions over the next six months," the Fed said.
Indexes that measure new orders and future shipments remained positive during April but remained positive.

title: Reports: Harvey Weinstein tests positive for Covid-19 in Alden prison
summary:
Former movie producer Harvey Weinstein, who was transferred to Alden's Wende Correctional Facility last week, has tested positive for Covid-19, according to reports by Reuters and CNHI.
The head of the state corrections officers union said that Weinstein, who is serving a prison sentence for sexual assault and rape, tested positive Sunday and has been placed in isolation, according to Reuters.
Ogdensburg's Michael Powers, president of the New York State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Association, said that several staff members had been quarantined, according to Reuters.
The news was first reported by Joe Mahoney of CNHI newspapers, which include the Niagara Gazette and Plattsburgh's Press-Republican, who cited state prison officials.
A lawyer for Weinstein told Reuters on Sunday night that his legal team had not been notified of the coronavirus diagnosis.

title: Drug overdoses are soaring in WNY
summary:
Overdoses on drugs of all kinds – and not just injected drugs – are on the rise across Erie County and other parts of Western New York.
"We've had a tremendous amount of fatal overdoses," Erie County Health Commissioner Dr. Gale Burstein said Friday as she showed a graph displaying a spike in the number of fatal deaths from overdoses.
It showed that there were 28 deaths in March that are suspected overdoses.
The overdoses are taking place throughout the community and in public places – from motel rooms to supermarket bathrooms.
Two fatal overdoses and three non-fatal overdoses were reported from Sunday to Tuesday, officials said.

title: Jody Lomeo to stay on as Kaleida CEO through crisis
summary:
Kaleida Health CEO Jody Lomeo will stay at the helm of the region's largest hospital system through the end of the coronavirus pandemic, despite having announced plans two months ago to retire at the end of this year.
As a result, Kaleida has suspended indefinitely its active search for a new CEO, which was about to kick off when the Covid-19 health crisis hit the Western New York region.
We’ll take it up at an appropriate time whenever this thing is behind us," said Frank Curci, Kaleida board chairman and CEO of Tops Markets.
He referred to Kaleida as his "family at work," and said he would even stay past his contract if necessary.
So Lomeo said he spoke with Curci and the board, who agreed that "now is not the time to contemplate this."

title: City Hall didn’t secure 1st order of COVID-19 supplies for NYC until March 6
summary:

title: A small Missouri city wants Tesla to build its Cybertruck factory there — and is offering $1 billion in incentives to make it happen
summary:
A small city in Missouri is offering Tesla some $1 billion in financial incentives to build a factory.
The city wants Elon Musk to build its Cybertruck there, it said in a website custom-built to court the electric automaker this week, and it's offering more than $1 billion in tax incentives to make it happen.
Musk said in March that he was "scouting locations" for another gigafactory to build the yet-to-be-sold Cybertruck.
In Buffalo, New York, Tesla received $750 million in similar incentives for a solar panel factory co-operated with Panasonic.
"Demand has been incredible," Musk said in January of the Cybertruck, which Tesla unveiled in November 2018.

title: Facing Sex-Abuse Claims, Buffalo Diocese Declares Bankruptcy
summary:
ALBANY, N.Y. — The Diocese of Buffalo filed for federal bankruptcy on Friday, becoming the latest entity to seek financial protection after a 2019 state law allowed victims of historical childhood sexual assault to sue.
The Catholic diocese, the largest in upstate New York, cited the Child Victims Act in a statement posted on its website, saying that the maneuver was necessary “to continue uninterrupted its mission throughout Western New York, while working to settle claims with existing Diocesan assets and insurance coverages.”The Child Victims Act was passed last year by the Democratic Legislature in Albany, after years of opposition from religious groups and private schools, among others.
It created a so-called look-back window, starting in August and lasting one year, allowing old claims that had passed the statute of limitations to be revived.
Hundreds of lawsuits were filed against the Catholic Church in the days after the look-back window opened, with more than 1,000 complaints brought under the Child Victims Act by Jan. 31, according to victims’ advocates.
The sheer volume of claims led to speculation that one or more of the eight dioceses in New York could declare bankruptcy.

title: Here’s the final snowfall tally for Feb. 7 Upstate NY record storm (chart)
summary:
Syracuse, N.Y. -- Upstate New York received an unambiguous message from winter on Friday: It ain’t over yet.
Syracuse had 9.2 inches, beating the Feb. 7 record of 6.4 inches, set in 1995.
Binghamton’s 8 inches fell just a third of an inch from the record, set in 1986.
The storm cut a ribbon of heavy snowfall through Upstate from the central Southern Tier to the very top northeast corner of the state.
In most areas, snow fell intensely for several hours before retreating.

title: Harold H. Izard, 80, state assemblyman, Sweet Home biology teacher
summary:
July 4, 1939 – Feb. 2, 2020Harold H. Izard, a former New York State assemblyman and Sweet Home High School biology teacher, had a passion for science, politics and life.
Mr. Izard, 80, died Feb. 2 in Buffalo General Medical Center after a brief illness.
Mr. Izard served as assemblyman for the 140th District in 1975-76.
From 1962 to 1975, Mr. Izard taught biology at Sweet Home High School.
Mr. Izard was known to wear a Russian aviator’s hat, and it seemed he had an unending supply of camouflage gear he wore often.

title: 'See It Through Buffalo' being screened at United Nations forum
summary:
'See It Through Buffalo' being screened at United Nations forumStill from the documentary short "See It Through Buffalo."
“Buffalo and the work of our faculty and students have much to contribute to this crucial global conversation on urban issues.”BUFFALO, N.Y. — Buffalo’s story of place is being shared with mayors, ministers, journalists and thousands of others attending the United Nations’ 10th World Urban Forum this week in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.
“See It Through Buffalo” is an official selection of the inaugural UN-Habitat Better Cities Film Festival and will be screened today (Feb. 12) in Abu Dhabi.
The festival, organized in partnership with First+Main Films, features documentary and fictional films from around the world on urban issues, including the theme of this year’s World Urban Forum — Cities of Opportunities: Connecting Culture and Innovation.
The World Urban Forum is the world’s largest and most important conference on urban issues.

title: Have a hot date for Valentine's Day? You can park for free on your lunch or dinner date in Buffalo
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — If you have a lunch or a dinner date in the City of Buffalo for Valentine's Day, you'll be able to save some money on parking.
Mayor Byron Brown, Buffalo City Council President Darius Pridgen and Councilmembers say that users of the Buffalo Roam Mobile Parking Payment App will be able to park for free on their lunch or dinner dates.
Free parking applies to any user of the app at hourly metered locations between 11 a.m. and 5 p.m.
If you haven't signed up for the Buffalo Roam app, you'll receive the free parking deal on Valentine's Day in addition to $2.14 off your next parking session through the end of February.
New users can enter the validation code '716716' to receive $2.14 off for a one-time parking session through February 29th.

summary:

Esther was a 60 year resident of the City of Tonawanda and served her community in multiple capacities.
She was also an active member of Salem United Church of Christ.

title: Mayor Brown goes after delinquent landlords
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB)–The Mayor of Buffalo says he’s going after delinquent building owners whose properties have become unsafe or dangerous.
“We cannot allow absentee or apathetic landlords to let their commercial properties fall into a state of disrepair,” said Mayor Byron Brown.
The City of Buffalo unveiled its plan Saturday to better ensure that commercial properties are structurally sound.
Brown says his administration will identify unstable structures sooner, expand the authority the city needs to intervene quickly when landlords are not cooperating, and more aggressively compel compliance.
He says a list is already made of 250 “Worst of the worst” properties and that inspection blitzes will begin immediately.

title: Harvey Weinstein assigned to a maximum security prison in upstate New York
summary:
(CNN) After a brief stay at Rikers Island, disgraced movie mogul Harvey Weinstein is moving to a prison in upstate New York.
The former producer has been assigned to the Wende Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison in Alden, New York, an official with the New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision told CNN.
The jail, which is just east of Buffalo, New York, houses more than 950 inmates, including Mark David Chapman, who was convicted of murdering musician John Lennon.
Weinstein is expected to stay at Wende for an undetermined period of time while authorities determine which facility meets his "security, medical, mental health and other needs," according to a Department of Corrections and Community Supervision release, obtained by CNN.
The correction department's guidelines note that prisoners with more than six years in their sentences are housed in maximum security facilities.

title: Brendan Cody, student at City Honors School
summary:
Jan. 4, 2003 - March 2, 2020Brendan Cody's classmates at City Honors School remember how he always tried to make them feel better.
After sharing the disappointment with Brendan during their second-period Chinese class, Brendan signed out of class – writing "cake" as the reason for leaving class – and brought the cake to his third-period biology class where he convinced the students to eat it.
His compassion for others extended to the squash court, said Tom Hayes, Brendan's squash coach at the Buffalo Club.
Brendan would ease up in a match if leading by too many points to let his opponent score, Hayes said.
"All the guys on our team absolutely loved him," said Hayes, his squash coach since Brendan was a 5-year-old.

title: Neither of Buffalo’s St. Patrick’s parades will take place this weekend
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — Both St. Patrick’s weekend parades will not take place as previously scheduled, Buffalo Mayor Byron Brown announced Thursday.
Buffalo is renowned around the country as having one of the largest St. Patrick’s weekend celebrations, with two parades: The neighborhood parade on Saturday in the Old First Ward and the city’s official one down Delaware Avenue on Sunday.
The Delaware Avenue parade was outright canceled, while organizers of the “Old Neighborhood” parade vowed to march down South Park Avenue and Hamburg Street in September 2020.
In recent years, police estimated 50,000 people attended the OFW parade and Brown said the Delaware Avenue parade attracted some 100,000.

title: Winter Weather Outlook 2019: Andy and Aaron's predictions for the season ahead
summary:
All said, these are good indicators for the path polar plunges will take through the winter season.
Early on, the coldest air will remain over the Midwest, but later in the winter season, weather patterns will shift allowing arctic air to lock in for the long haul.
As this push of polar air makes its way across Western New York our snow totals will begin to pile up.
We expect a harsh second half to the winter season and by the time all is said and done our snow totals will be above normal for the 2019-2020 winter season.
The winter season may take its time to ramp up but by the end of the season we can expect below normal temperatures with above normal snow totals.

title: Victor Olofsson named NHL's "Rookie of the Month" for October
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WKBW) — The Buffalo Sabres Victor Olofsson has been named the NHL's "Rookie of the Month" for the month of October.
Olofsson finished the month of October with six goals and four assists for a total of 10 points in 13 games.
The six goals scored this season all came on the power play.
The Swedish born winger also recorded both of his goals in the 2018-19 season on the power play, making him the first player in NHL history to record his first eight goals on the power play.
Olofsson was selected for the honor over Toronto Maple Leafs right wing Ilya Mikheyev, Vancouver Canucks defenseman Quinn Hughes, Colorado Avalanche defenseman Cale Makar and Washington Capitals goaltender Ilya Samsonov.

title: Do the Rangers have a faceoff problem?
summary:
Chances are you have heard and/or read that faceoff percentage is an overvalued statistic.
The RangersNow that we have established that team faceoff percentage data is overrated, let’s look at how the Rangers have done on the dot over the last two decades.
Before the 2019-20 season was postponed, the Rangers had the second-worst team faceoff percentage in the league (46.6), ahead of only the Buffalo Sabres (45.9).
Interestingly enough, the Rangers haven’t broke even in team faceoff percentage since the 2012-13 season and haven’t eclipsed 50% since the 2008-09 season.
So team faceoff percentage has been an area of concern and potential weakness for the Rangers since the team’s top three centers were Scott Gomez, Chris Drury, and Brandon Dubinsky.

title: Can trick-or-treating be moved to another day?
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. — Forecasts show a pretty abysmal Halloween night.
For that reason, a number of our viewers took to our social media pages asking the question: Is it possible for trick-or-treating to be moved to another day?
BuffaloCity of Buffalo spokesman Mike DeGeorge told 2 On Your Side that shifting Halloween trick-or-treating times to a different day is not out of the realm of possibility, but they're having their Department of Public Works keep an eye on the weather.
He explained that changing the day could just lead to confusion and headaches because there would still be kids out trick-or-treating Halloween night despite the weather, leading to two nights of kids out knocking on doors for candy.
HamburgTown Supervisor Jim Shaw told 2 On Your Side that the Hamburg Town Board accepted a resolution on Monday that October 31 would be designated Halloween Trick-or-Treating Night for the town.

summary:

According to the Erie County District’s Attorney’s Office, Evelyn Soto allegedly killed Luis Alicea by beating him with a metal object.
The incident happened inside an apartment on Ivy Street in Buffalo back in October 2019.
Soto is being held without bail.
If convicted, Soto faces 25 years to life in prison.

title: WNY Land Conservancy trying to save "Mossy Point" in Wales from being developed
summary:
In between Kenneglenn Nature preserve and Hunter's Creek County Park is a privately owned piece of land called Mossy Point.
The owner has a deal with the WNY Land Conservancy to sell the 222 acre property for $1.6 million.
The Land Conservancy has already raised $1.1 million and needs to raise $500,000 more to purchase the land and make it open to the public.
There will be a silent auction and 42 North Brewing has made a special Mossy Point IPA.
"This place is threatened and we don't have a lot of time and it's a really cool place," Jajean Rose Burney, Deputy Director for the WNY Land Conservancy said.

title: WNY gets off easy on climate change, again – The Buffalo News
summary:
September was the hottest September on record globally, following the second hottest August, the hottest month on record of any month, July, and the hottest June on record globally.
In any case, September marked the fourth hottest on record month globally this year, so far.
And the hottest of any month on record, July, was only 2.9 degrees above average in Buffalo.
Our hottest days near Buffalo generally occur when the wind comes from the south or the southeast, bearing no lake influence.
All of us will be impacted by some of the economic, public health and demographic impacts of warming climate change.

title: Phil Collins celebrates fathers, sons, old friends and timeless tunes at KeyBank Center
summary:
About halfway though his performance at KeyBank Center on Friday, Phil Collins pulled the chair he’d been sitting on throughout the show right to the edge of the drum riser at the rear of the stage.
Collins’ 17-year-old son, Nicholas, was manning the kit, and his father appeared to be enraptured by his playing, as was the full house out front.
Collins, one of the greatest drummers in the history of rock and pop music, can no longer play, back and neck problems and several surgeries having robbed us of his iconic, fiery, virtuosic drumming style.
This fact made the exchange between father and son at the set’s midpoint all the more poignant.
For his part, Collins broke into unabashed tears when, after he introduced young Nic, the crowd erupted into an extended ovation.

title: ‘World-class’ beer fest coming to Buffalo this fall
summary:

The Festival, sponsored by the beer import company Shelton Brothers, takes place at the restored Buffalo Central Terminal Oct. 4 and 5.
“You’d have to spend months and countless dollars for a chance to meet this many world-class brewers,” Shelton Brothers boasts in its description of the event.
The list of brewers pouring at the Buffalo fest is still a work in progress, but expect plenty of traditional European styles mixed with heavy doses of wild, barrel-aged, sour and flavor-infused selections.
Shelton Brothers is based in Belchertown, Mass.

title: Record-breaking Halloween rain brings severe flooding to Upstate NY
summary:
Syracuse, N.Y. -- A Halloween storm that dropped record-breaking rain on Upstate New York caused widespread flooding, while high winds this morning knocked out power to thousands.
While the rain tapered off early this morning, the weather service said many creeks could keep rising until 8 a.m.
In Chautauqua County, a gust of 61 mph was recorded, the weather service said.
One spotter in Herkimer County recorded 4.95 inches, the weather service said.
In adjoining Oneida County, where more than 3 inches of rain was recorded, County Executive Anthony Picente declared a state of emergency.

title: Department of Health reveals what's behind the 'cancer cluster'
summary:
BUFFALO N.Y. (WKBW) — Areas of Erie County have been identified as a 'cancer cluster' and now, the Department of Health has some answers.
The DOH conducted studies of the area to find out why there are higher rates of cancer.
"One possible explanation for the higher rates of cancer were that there are much higher rates of tobacco use among the population of the study area," said Brad Hutton, Deputy Commissioner of Public Health for the New York State Health Department.
The state Health Department has been doing research about what’s causing the “cancer cluster” in our community.
Governor Andrew Cuomo announced a $675,000 grant to help address the cancer cluster.

title: New York’s flavored e-cigarette ban delayed by courts
summary:
Efforts to ban flavored e-cigarettes and reduce their appeal to youngsters have sputtered under industry pressure in over a half-dozen states this year.
A proposed ban that President Donald Trump outlined Wednesday, Sept. 11, would supersede any state inaction and includes a ban on mint and menthol.
(AP Photo/Robert F. Bukaty)NEW YORK STATE (via WROC) — New York state’s ban on flavored e-cigarette and vaping products was scheduled to go into effect Friday, but now that ban is being delayed by state courts.
Officials from Vapor Technology Associated say a New York State Appellate Division Court granted a temporary restraining order Thursday in a lawsuit the VTA and other pro-vaping affiliates lobbied against the state.
So, for now, the ban on flavored e-cigarettes is on hold.

title: Powerball-playing North Evans retiree is Erie County's newest millionaire
summary:
David Yax of North Evans went to bed Sept. 4, unaware that he was the winner of a Powerball jackpot drawing.
"I had no idea how many people had won, or if I was the only one," he said Tuesday.
As it turned out, the 75-year-old, retired union carpenter is Erie County’s newest multimillionaire.
The winning Sept. 4 Powerball jackpot purchase marked the first in Western New York since the state joined the Multi-State Lottery Association in 2010, according to New York Lottery officials.
The previous lottery jackpot record winner in Western New York was Joseph Cotton of Alden, who won a $33.3 million Lotto jackpot in 1991.

As a freshman at Chipola in 2018-19, Zachery averaged 8.5 points, 5.8 assists and 3.9 rebounds in 32 games.
“This whole year was stressful,” said Zachery, who redshirted this season at Chipola and has three years of eligibility remaining.
Zachery said he signed his national letter of intent with the Bulls on Wednesday, the start of the spring signing period for men’s and women’s basketball.

title: Coldest first half of November on record in Buffalo
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. — As of Friday afternoon, the high temperature at the Buffalo Airport was just 35 degrees.
This prolonged and progressively more intense cold spell has gotten November 2019 off to the coldest start for the month on record.
That breaks the old record for the coldest first 15 days of the month by a full degree.
As of Friday afternoon, Lake Erie's water temperature was 46 degrees near Buffalo.
That's 3 degrees below normal for the date and 3 degrees above the record low for the date.

title: How much snow fell (so far) in Upstate NY storm Nov. 11/12? (chart)

The National Weather Service reports that the snowiest place so far in Duane Center, in the Adirondacks county of Franklin.
Western New York wasn’t far behind, with Buffalo and Rochester each accumulating 10.9 inches and setting new records for Nov. 11.
Buffalo received 8.7 inches before midnight, which beat the previous Nov. 11 record of 5.3 inches, set in 1942.
Rochester had 8.2 inches by midnight, breaking the old Nov. 11 record of 5.2 inches, set in 1991.

title: N.Y.C. Weather: Winter Arrives Early, Possibly Bringing Snow
summary:
The forecast calls for our coldest weather so far this season.
As a result of a cold front, temperatures are expected to drop into the 40s on Tuesday morning, with rain in the forecast, too.
With the mercury expected to plunge toward freezing by the afternoon, the rain could turn into the first snow of the season.
“We’re not really looking at accumulation in the city — it could be a brief period of lighter snow or could just end up as rain,” said Jay Engle, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service.
“But north and west of the city, we’ll get light amounts of snow.”On Tuesday morning, the National Weather Service said the city could see less than a half inch of snow during the day.

Henry “Hank” Steinbrenner died Tuesday, April 14, 2020, at his home in Clearwater, Fla.
(AP Photo/Kathy Willens, File)NEW YORK (AP) — Hank Steinbrenner, the oldest son of George Steinbrenner and one of the four siblings who own the controlling shares of the New York Yankees, died Tuesday at age 63.
George Steinbrenner died in July 2010 and wife Joan died in December 2018.
A rock fan, Hank Steinbrenner kept a Fender Stratocaster guitar on the floor near the door of his office at the Yankees’ spring training ballpark.

summary:

The winter storm warning is in place from 8 a.m. Monday to 6 a.m. Tuesday and includes most of Western New York.
A winter storm watch was issued just before noon Sunday, and updated to a storm warning just before 8 p.m.
According to the National Weather Service, a winter storm warning is issued when a significant combination of hazardous winter weather is occurring or imminent.
A storm warning indicates heavy snow of at least 6 inches in 12 hours, or at least 8 inches in 24 hours, is expected.

title: Nov. 18, 2014: The wall of snow moves in ... and parks
summary:
This week, The Buffalo News recounts one of the most memorable storms to strike Western New York.
There was only one reasonable reaction to the sight of the sky in downtown Buffalo the afternoon of Tuesday, Nov. 18, 2014: Wow.
As it moved over the balmy Great Lakes, that unforgettable cloud picked up moisture and then dumped snow over the region’s southern half.
In less than 24 hours, more than 60 inches fell on the region from roughly South Buffalo southward.
So much snow fell so quickly that area highway crews could not keep up.

title: Rain, Then the First Snow of the Season in the New York Area
summary:
A winter weather advisory from the National Weather Service is in effect for much of the region until 7 a.m. Tuesday, with a winter storm warning in parts of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.
Forecasters warned that New York City and Long Island could expect to see about two to four inches of snow by Monday night, with up to 10 inches in some suburban areas.
Pounding rain had been predicted for the city in the early morning, but the worst of the storm was apparently sparing the city during the beginning of the commute.
Forecasters also warned that heavy winds and wet snow could result in a number of downed tree limbs and power outages in the New York City area, a prediction reminiscent of an snowstorm last November, when similar conditions crippled the region and brought commutes to a standstill.
As with that storm, weather conditions were expected to worsen over time on Monday, with temperatures dropping and winds rising just in time for evening rush hour.

title: Here’s what the November 2014 storm was like for a meteorologist – The Buffalo News
summary:
(Something like this happened in 1945 in a lake-effect storm, when more than 70 inches fell in parts of Lancaster, but in the more recent era, the November storm of 2014 stands alone in many ways.)
Most of those 4 inches fell at the onset of the storm, when the developing band swung briefly north of the city after starting briefly south, before settling into its “stationarity” farther south.
Close to South Buffalo, up to 48 inches fell by Nov. 20, and up to 7 feet fell in portions of the nearby Buffalo and more distant Erie County Southtowns, as well as in eastern suburbs such as Lancaster and Depew.
Take my word for it – this is about as classic an upper air setup for big-time lake snow can get.
This monster storm lived up to expectations and, in a few spots south of Buffalo, exceeded early extreme expectation.

title: Troopers dressed as highway workers issue 1,048 traffic tickets
summary:
New York State Police issued 1,048 tickets statewide during special traffic enforcement details at work zones, state officials said.
During "Operation Hardhat," troopers dressed as highway workers, while stationed in active work zones, targeting motorists not following posted work zone speed limits.
State Police conducted 28 details at state Department of Transportation work zones and four details along the length of the New York State Thruway, starting in August and continuing through early November.
We urge all motorists to slow down, move over and use extreme caution when encountering road work or emergency operations along the highway."
"Operation Hardhat" is a joint initiative by State Police, the New York State Department of Transportation and the New York State Thruway Authority.

summary:

Power outages were sporadic, with some later in the afternoon in the city of Buffalo, but with restoration times estimated at early evening.
Because of that, National Grid wants people to be ready to take proper action when dealing with it.

title: Grandmother believes hoverboard charging cord caused South Buffalo fire
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — Just before 2 a.m. on Thursday, a fire forced two adults, their eight biological children and a foster child out of their home.
Nine children live at the home: Eight biological children and one foster child, including a five-day-old baby who came home from the hospital on Monday.
While it’s not clear how the fire started, as firefighters investigate, the grandmother says that the fire began due to a hoverboard charging cord which the family used for the first time that night.
Some of the family members are already being released from the hospital.
2 adults and 9 children have to stay with other family members while their house is fixed up.

title: Remembering the November Storm, 5 Years Later
summary:
Five years ago right now, large portions of Western New York were in the middle of a historic lake effect snowstorm.
A wall of lake effect snow pummeled a 15 to 20 mile area, including South Buffalo, Hamburg, Lackawanna, Lancaster, Orchard Park and West Seneca.
It quickly earned a comparison to another infamous Western New York storm — the Blizzard of ‘77.
It was clear in the northtowns but it quickly became clear people in the storm were experiencing something historic.
The November Storm went down as one of the largest ever American snow storms in a 24 hour period.

There is a maximum limit of one voucher per person.
All birds collected this year will benefit the Buffalo City Mission and FeedMore WNY.

title: Wintry mix, possible ice storm for WNY in Sunday forecast
summary:
A wintry mix of precipitation and a possible ice storm are in store for Western New York on Sunday, according to the National Weather Service.
The NWS issued a hazardous weather outlook early Friday morning for Western New York on Sunday that includes mixed wintry precipitation, including some freezing rain and possible minor ice accumulations.
The forecast is for all counties within Western New York and others extending to the east into northern Central New York.
"Those with travel plans across the region late this weekend should stay tuned for the latest forecast information and any statements regarding this next round of wintry weather," the NWS stated.
The Sunday forecast calls for rain, snow, freezing rain and sleet before 2 p.m., snow between 2 and 4 p.m. and rain after 4 p.m.

summary:

The Medicaid deficit driversThere are many explanations offered for the Medicaid red ink.

Derick Brassard's fluke goal at 5:19 of the first period gave the New York Islanders the lead and they made it stand up to blank the Sabres, 1-0, Saturday night in KeyBank Center.
It's the first time this season they have dropped two straight games in regulation.
Meanwhile, the Islanders (10-3) won their ninth straight game for the first time since 1990 and have allowed just 16 goals in that stretch.

title: Lake-effect bands crank up for high terrain south of Buffalo
summary:
Lake-effect bands had dumped 3 to 5 inches of snow as of Sunday morning in the higher elevations of southern Erie County and the Southern Tier, the National Weather Service in Buffalo said.
The Weather Service predicted lake-effect snow will move into metro Buffalo around sunset with a mix of rain and flakes but with no real accumulation.
"Elevation did matter," Weather Service meteorologist Kirk Apffel said as he noted the towns that saw the most snow Saturday night and Sunday morning.
In lower-lying areas – Jamestown in Chautauqua County, for example – no snow was measured as of Sunday morning, Apffel said.
The winter weather advisory for lake-effect snow in the high terrain of southern Erie and the Southern Tier counties was slated to continue until 1 p.m. Sunday.

title: Buffalo Wild Wings Manager Dies After Chemical Incident
summary:
A Buffalo Wild Wings general manager died and 13 workers and patrons were sickened after being exposed to a toxic mixture of cleaning agents at a Massachusetts location on Thursday evening, the authorities said.
The Fire Department in Burlington, about 12 miles northwest of Boston, responded to calls at the restaurant and found a man outside being treated by paramedics, Assistant Fire Chief Michael Patterson said at a news conference on Thursday.
The episode occurred after a restaurant employee mixed an acidic detergent called Scale Kleen with a bleach-like cleaner sold as Super 8 to clean the kitchen floor, causing a chemical reaction, the authorities said.
That person, who the authorities said was not the manager who died, exited the restaurant to get fresh air.

The old record was 16 degrees set back in 1986.

title: Erie County DWI arrests drop significantly over decade
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (WIVB) — When compared to the first half of the decade, DWI arrests in Erie County have drastically dropped.
Citing data from STOP-DWI and New York State police, county officials noted that in 2011, there were 3,445 DWI arrests in the county.
“With the extended weekend coming up, it is important that people drive responsibly on our roadways,” Erie County Executive Mark Poloncarz said.
County officials, including Poloncarz, shared graphs of the DWI statistics, including how much it costs someone, on average.
According to a SUNY Potsdam study, drivers usually end up paying around $10,000 after being charged with DWI.

title: What Are AFC East Teams Doing to Prep for a Tom Brady–less World?
summary:
New England’s reign hasn’t lasted that long, but forgive their AFC East rivals if it feels like it has.
Since New England’s reign began in 2001, the Patriots have won the AFC East in 17 of 19 seasons (89.5 percent).
While the Patriots have been basking in the spotlight, the Dolphins, Bills, and Jets have been trapped in darkness.
Which of the three other AFC East teams are using this opportunity to reach toward the light?
The more consequential chapter for football history—and the most harrowing scenario for the Bills, Jets, and Dolphins—is what happens if the Patriots empire replaces Brady seamlessly.

“This whole year was stressful,” said Zachery, who redshirted this season at Chipola and has three years of eligibility remaining.

title: Biggest surprises and disappointments for New Jersey Devils
summary:
Here we take a look at the surprises and disappointments for the New Jersey Devils .
Subban‘s tough seasonThe addition of Subban (via trade with the Nashville Predators) was one of the highlights of the Devils’ offseason.
In his first year with the Devils Subban struggled through what is certainly the worst single-season performance of his career.

title: Poor travel conditions expected as lake-effect band blows back towards Southtowns
summary:
Evening commuters heading to the Southtowns might want to take it easy as a lake-effect snow band that dumped 3 inches of snow in the Buffalo metro area this morning drifts back south.
"It's out of the City of Buffalo, but the southern Buffalo metro can still expect some poor travel conditions," said Heather Kenyon, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport in Cheektowaga.
"It's going to settle across the Southern Tier and then diminish, so we're not expecting it to move back into the Buffalo metro area tonight," said Kenyon.
Like the morning, blowing snow is expected with winds of up to 40 mph possible.

title: Early arrival of flu strikes thousands across New York State
summary:
A lot more people than usual spent the holidays at home or in the hospital with the flu, thanks to an early arrival of the contagious respiratory illness in New York State.
In Erie County, reported flu cases more than doubled each week of December, climbing from 29 cases the first week to 345 cases the last week of the year.
The state Health Department reported 10,085 laboratory-confirmed cases of the flu statewide during the week ending Jan. 4.
The numbers are underreported because not everyone who gets the flu seeks treatment, and not all cases that test positive are reported to the state.
Seniors, pregnant women and children under age 2 are considered at high risk for the flu, according to health experts.

title: Facing Sex-Abuse Claims, Buffalo Diocese Declares Bankruptcy
summary:
ALBANY, N.Y. — The Diocese of Buffalo filed for federal bankruptcy on Friday, becoming the latest entity to seek financial protection after a 2019 state law allowed victims of historical childhood sexual assault to sue.
The Catholic diocese, the largest in upstate New York, cited the Child Victims Act in a statement posted on its website, saying that the maneuver was necessary “to continue uninterrupted its mission throughout Western New York, while working to settle claims with existing Diocesan assets and insurance coverages.”The Child Victims Act was passed last year by the Democratic Legislature in Albany, after years of opposition from religious groups and private schools, among others.
It created a so-called look-back window, starting in August and lasting one year, allowing old claims that had passed the statute of limitations to be revived.
Hundreds of lawsuits were filed against the Catholic Church in the days after the look-back window opened, with more than 1,000 complaints brought under the Child Victims Act by Jan. 31, according to victims’ advocates.
The sheer volume of claims led to speculation that one or more of the eight dioceses in New York could declare bankruptcy.

title: Applications across New York soar under Green Light Law
summary:
BUFFALO, N.Y. — Call it a deluge at the DMV.
“We’ve been very, very busy,” confirmed New York State Motor Vehicles Commissioner Mark Schroeder, regarding a rush on Department of Motor Vehicles offices since the state’s controversial Green Light Law when into effect one month ago.
Once they obtain the learners permit, they may obtain a standard license as early as six months later, if they also pass a road test.
Long lines of those seeking to get a license have been witnessed, mostly at DMV offices in New York City and downstate regions.

title: As New York State faces a $6.1B deficit, talk of tax hikes creep up
summary:
ALBANY – In 2020, state officials will examine whether to turn to New York residents and businesses for more tax revenues.
The new state budget is due in March, and Democrats who control the state Capitol are already talking about potentially major tax hikes on wealthy individuals and corporations.
Rank-and-file lawmakers kicked off talk about potential tax hikes two weeks ago after Gov.
Nor will such tax hikes, he insisted over the objections of some fiscal watchdogs, push wealthy people to leave New York.
Trickle down tax hikesIn the past decade, much of the lobbying and media attention has gone to tax hikes targeting high-income earners, such as the 8.82% top tax bracket on people with annual incomes of $1 million and above.

title: The Fishing Beat (Dec. 11, 2019)
summary:
Musky season will close in the lower Niagara River after Dec. 15.
Despite the turbid conditions, shore anglers have been picking up some steelhead, brown trout and lake trout.
Remember that if you do catch a lake trout in New York waters, it should be released immediately.
Muskellunge season remains open in the Lower Niagara River, Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River through Dec. 15.
For Lake Ontario, one proposal would extend the lake trout season by one month, moving from Jan. 1 to Dec. 1.

title: Winter Weather Outlook 2019: Andy and Aaron's predictions for the season ahead
summary:
All said, these are good indicators for the path polar plunges will take through the winter season.
Early on, the coldest air will remain over the Midwest, but later in the winter season, weather patterns will shift allowing arctic air to lock in for the long haul.
As this push of polar air makes its way across Western New York our snow totals will begin to pile up.
We expect a harsh second half to the winter season and by the time all is said and done our snow totals will be above normal for the 2019-2020 winter season.
The winter season may take its time to ramp up but by the end of the season we can expect below normal temperatures with above normal snow totals.

title: Outbreak of highly contagious virus among babies prompts warning
summary:
An outbreak of a common and highly contagious respiratory virus among babies in the area has prompted a warning from pediatricians at Oishei Children’s Hospital.
ICU usually has 20 RSV cases.
Oishei Children’s Hospital responded to the outbreak by opening up additional areas to treat RSV cases, adding six more beds to the PICU as well as supplementing emergency treatment.
“Generally, we’re seeing babies less than one year of age presenting initially with cold symptoms, but they can develop pretty significant breathing problems," said Turkovich.
"RSV is the most common cause of pneumonia in kids less than a year of age.”
